description:
A three-dimensional treasure hunt on an multi-layered island.
Lasercut with magnetic tiles to hold tools and secret artifacts.

Dig through the several layers to uncover artifacts needed to recover treasures:

     terrain
     tools
     strata.


Uncover tools needed to dig deeper.

Terrain includes fields, forest, rocks, ruins and swamps.

Somewhat akin to the Treasure of Oak Island.

—description from the designer

Inventures, Birtle Game’s first title, is a collaborative storytelling adventure game coming soon to Kickstarter.

In each game, players create their own characters and go on challenging adventures together. Victory comes down to how well you know your character and fellow players.

In Inventures, there’re no dice, game master, or numbers to track. Instead, Inventures relies on a powerful and novel game mechanic involving symbol interpretation.

When your character faces a challenge, you choose between options, each composed of a randomly drawn ACTION and OBJECT card.

You secretly pick which option best represents how your character would solve the problem. If the other players successfully guess which option you chose, your action succeeds and the story progresses.

Because of its modular symbol interpretation system, you can use Inventures to play stories in any setting imaginable: Westerns, SciFi, Fantasy, or a game set in the world of your favorite books or movies!

Games can be as short as 45 minutes and as long as weeklong campaigns.

—description from the designer

Alphabet Dungeon is a two to four player game where a group of stalwart adventurers go on a quest for treasure tiles.  You will be exploring a mysterious dungeon, fighting monsters and searching for treasure tiles.  In this dungeon the treasures are letters and your goal is to solve all the words on your quest.  As you explore the dungeon and defeat monsters you gain more letters to help solve more words.  The player that completes his/her entire quest of words wins the game.  During your exploration you can visit the bazaar and purchase vowels to help you complete your quest.

VICTORY CONDITIONS:
When a player completes all the quest words on his/her quest card, they win the game.  The Bonus word is used in case of a tie where both players complete their quest card on the same turn, the player that has also completed the bonus word would end up being the winner.  If both players complete all words and the bonus word on the same turn, then both players share the win.

-description from designer

Players pick two cards, adjective and noun, and try to figure out third,suitable word for both of these words. If two players come up with the same word, both get points.

—user summary

Ruh-roh, Shaggy! There's a monster on the loose, and it's scaring everyone out of town! It's up to the Mystery Inc. gang to stop them! Scooby-Doo! The Board Game is a co-operative family game for 1-5 players that brings the beloved cartoon series to life with amazing miniatures of the whole gang.

Players take on the role of Scooby-Doo, Fred, Velma, Daphne or Shaggy, and ride the Mystery Machine around town, building traps to catch the villains before they frighten all the citizens away — but just like in our favorite episodes, even the best plans can go awry as the monster, which is controlled by the game itself, may make a move the players never expected!

Each member of Mystery, Inc. has their own unique, special ability to help them during the game, and they'll need all the help they can get because the villains all operate differently as well! The gang can succeed only if they coordinate together as a group.

Scooby-Doo! The Board Game has three levels of difficulty (easy/medium/hard) and special rules for playing as a two-player game or a solo game.

—description from the publisher

You are stranded on a desert island. Use the resources at your disposal to make life more comfortable and/or increase your chances of rescue. Get points for developing your island. But will you try to make a home on this tropical paradise or do everything you can to get out of there?

Castaway is a 'roll and write' game. One player rolls the dice and each player decides how they will use the dice rolls on their own board. The dice show the coordinates on the map and indicate the area you must work on each turn. The choice of action within that area is yours. Will you cut down trees or plant new ones? Will you build a shelter or plunder a shipwreck? The choice is yours.

The game finishes when one player is rescued, abandoned or becomes self-sustained.

Castaway is a 'Placemat' game - a game contained entirely within an A3 placemat (including the rules). Just add two standard D6 dice.

On the reverse side of each placemat is a second game - Beach Life.

Both games have a desert island theme.

—description from the designer

Nemesis Lockdown is the first stand alone expansion to Nemesis. During the game, players will be taken to a totally new location - a secret base on Mars, represented by a multi level board. Lockdown will retain the highly cinematic, semi-co-op experience of the original game, while introducing a lot of new, fresh mechanics.

During the tense gameplay, you and your fellow players will gather items, explore different rooms and use your actions, craft, run, and fight other species. At the same time, every player will try to complete their secret objective, that will grant them victory... Sometimes at the expense of others.

Some of the new mechanics are: 

     Multi-level base with stairs and elevators 
     Advanced computer actions
     CSS hatch system 
     Power and light on different levels 
     Contingency procedure 
     New characters and alien race

A variant of L.L.A.M.A.

Differences include:

     7 of each card instead of 8.
     Lower player count. 5 instead of 6.
     The game is over when a player reaches 50 points instead of 40.
     An additional single wild card. When played, it counts as 1 higher than the top card. When scoring, its value is equal to the last-played card.
     No tokens. Players must provide their own score-keeping method.
     Instead of returning tokens, a player who plays all their cards rolls two dice, which determine how many points are reduced from the score. The dice have the values 1,2,3,4,5,10. Your score can't go below 0.


—user summary

Mythic Coins Card Gameis a player vs player game where you control a mythic character such as a God, Goddess, or other powerful being.  Each character comes in their own Coin Deck.

A Coin Deck contains a coin, display stand, dice, and 108 cards themed to that character.

There is no shuffling or drawing cards. Players use the cards to build their character based on their vision of that character and strategy for the game.  A character can be customized to various power levels in the areas of Attack, Defense, Damage Bonus, Resistance, Health, Power, and Ability Cards.

There are over 50 unique Ability cards.  Players secretly choose a set number of Ability cards before the game. These are kept in a player's hand and only shown when used.  Most Ability cards require a specific amount of Power cards.

During a player's turn, they can choose to Activate a Character, Rest a Character, or Use a Card. Most cards result in a battle with another character. Some cards have other effects.

A player must protect their Health cards and manage their Power cards while attacking and defending against an enemy.  Many attacks are resolved by opposing dice rolls. However, other attacks/defenses are countered by your opponent's cards.

There is no board. The coin is placed on its display stand in front of the player.  The cards are placed next to the coin.

There is no limit to the number of players.  You can play in teams, a handicapped game, or other game modes.

Game balance is maintained since each deck has cards with the same abilities.  However, they are themed to fit the character.  An evasion defense may be called Flight for a Dragon but Teleportation for a Lich.

Every card has a counter.  More powerful cards cost more to use.  You can only use an Ability card once.  These things prevent one or two cards from dominating the game.

When not playing, coins can be used as display pieces since they come with a stand.

—description from the designer

The memo game for language lovers and wordsmiths. For 2 and more players. Playing time approx. 20 min. In the new memo game for language and pun lovers, pairs like "Bär" and "Tiger" result in the noun "BÄRTIGER". "Tang" and "Ente" become "TANGENTE", the nouns "Mode" and "Rat" form the German adjective "MODERAT". This game is full of surprises and trains the exact viewing of words. Each of the 36 pairs has its own background colour, which may be used as confirmation when searching for the correct word pairs. Only language grouches rely solely on the colours when searching for the pun pairs.

Discovering something special in every-day life and transforming it creatively – with the new memo game What is this? and a bit of skill anyone can achieve it. With motives by the renowned children's book illustrator Antje Damm, MeterMorphosen is finally introducing a memo game for children that is more challenging than the usual memo games as its pairs consist of two different motives. When you find everyday items like carrots, a clothespin or soap on the sturdy memo cards, the question is: What is this? With the matching second card, these every-day objects are transformed into animals: a sausage becomes a dachshund, and a popsicle unexpectedly turns into a penguin. The 24 pairs of What is this? promote associative thinking and thus support intelligence development through effortless play. This memo game is not only an assembly of marvellous ideas, but also an encouragement to examine the world more closely, to get creative and to use one's imagination.

An incredibly fun memo game for adults who are interested in the history of the 20th century. Just like in other memo games, the players have to find pairs – but actually, in this game there are always four of a kind! The four Beatles: John, Paul, George, and Ringo. Or four conservatives: Angela Merkel, Mother Teresa, Pope Jean Paul, and Margaret Thatcher. It is absolutely entertaining to spot the caricatures of prominent persons in the game and to discover their independent categorization. The players get to keep both cards if they find corresponding pairs, but if they find all four cards of a kind, they get additional points via an extra joker card that raises the pile of gained cards and helps them win the game in the end. There are 64 cards in the box.

Arty Mouse: Spin & Find game was developed to help children strengthen their memory and practice memory techniques. There are two ways of playing it - an easier and a more advanced mode.

The game has a spinner and tiles with characters. The characters are represented on the tiles multiple times in different environments and poses. The goal of the game is to find and get as many tiles as possible.

In the basic game mode, children first mark the back of the tiles. They can draw their unique markings, shapes and doodles that will help them remember what is on the other side. The tiles are then placed face-down. In the second part of the game they spin the spinner and find the character that the arrow points to among the face-down tiles. The player with the most tiles at the end of the game wins.

In the advanced game mode, extra tiles are added, with only some tiles marked, and additional rules apply that make the game even more challenging.

The rules include additional variants for a single player and cooperative gameplay.

—description from the publisher

It's the St. Lorenz's night and as per tradition, people gather under a starry sky to see their wishes granted by the shooting stars. What most people don't know is that, in order to realize a particular wish, you need cunning and strategy. You will have to capture the right comets to make your dreams come true. But be careful: if you chase love you will hardly realize the desire for richness, the same its true for those who chase fame, at the expense of virtue... Plan your moves carefully, and avoid the traps of your opponent: who first realizes two wishes... wins the game!

Comete is a language-independent, highly thematic strategy game, which hides a fascinating and delicate depth of play.

Comete is a "perfect strategy" game, where all the information is known to all players and the resources available for each player are identical: your choices will make the difference. But it's not an abstract game, shooting stars are elusive and unpredictable, and so they are in the game. No one can know what will be the next fallen star to appear in the sky, even less when the comet you need will appear. Moreover, they exist as in the past comets harbingers of feast or famine and often it will be up to the player to decide how to unravel the celestial message.

To capture a comet you will have to «attract» it to you by matching its colours. You have several «wish fragments» (acrylic gems) to play each turn, which you must tactically place by line of the celestial horizon: if a comet passing next to them has the same colours, you have captured it!

—description from the publisher

Autofarmer is a competitive card game about growing cannabis. Players take on the roles of gardeners and try to grow as many grams as possible.

Firstly, players need to prepare their gardens. This is achieved by rolling dice. They define the number of seeds players get and the luck of their germination. Thanks to the dice the size of a garden is different in each game. Players must adapt their strategy to it.
The game consists of three rounds - growth, blooming, and harvest. Each turn players draw three cards from the deck. They can swap these new cards once. Then you play them to boost your plants or sabotage others.
But don’t get fooled, the task will be indeed daunting. Not only natural disasters like molds or pests, but mainly the malevolence of other players lurk here as only one of you can become the best grower!

The game ends when the last player finishes the third round. Players count the yields from their gardens and write down the values. There will be as many games as there are players. Finally, the yields from all the player’s games add up.
The player with the most grams wins.

—description from the publisher

The main goal of Confabulation is to score points by spelling words. 
First, a category card is drawn and a category is chosen. This can be done by playing the categories in order, or by rolling a die or otherwise randomly selecting one if just one round is to be played. 
Second, each player is dealt 6 word cards, which have 3x3 grids of letters on them. A timer is set for three minutes. The players will use their own hand of cards to spell words in the selected category until the time runs out. 
The players can rearrange the cards as much as they would like; the cards can be rotated or overlapped. Players write down each word once they find it, then they can rearrange the cards (they don't have to preserve the configuration that allowed them to spell the word). 
When spelling words, any adjacent letters may be used, including diagonally-connected letters (similar to the mechanics of the game Boggle). Letters may only be used once in any given word. 
At the end of the round, points are counted. 3- and 4-letter words are worth one point, 5-letter words are worth 2 points, 6-letter words are worth 3 points, 7-letter words are worth 4 points, etc. 
Plural words do not count unless the word is naturally plural (eg. pants). Spelling the word 'mountains', for example, would count only as the 8-letter word 'mountain'.
Proper nouns DO count if it makes sense in the category. (For example, if the category is 'science terms' then the word 'Einstein' would be allowed).

Players can challenge the spelling of another player's word. If the spelling is incorrect, the word does not count. 
Players can play as many or as few rounds as they want.

Alternative scoring:
Instead of totaling the score of all words at the end of the round, the player who spelled the longest word in the three-minute time period is the winner.

Alternative gameplay:
Players can adjust the number of cards dealt to each player or the amount of time in a round.

—description from the designer

In Overboss, rival Boss Monsters emerge from their dungeons to conquer the Overworld. Each turn, players draft and place terrain tiles and monster tokens. Their goal: to craft the map with the greatest Power and become the ultimate Overboss!

Designed by Aaron Mesburne and Kevin Russ (Calico), this fast-paced game combines drafting, set collection, and puzzly tile laying. It's set in the retro-inspired pixel art world of Brotherwise Games' best-selling Boss Monster, but this is an entirely new experience.

Build your map by drafting Forests, Swamps, Caves, Camps, Graveyards, Dungeon Entrances and other landscapes. Each terrain type has a different point value, and some increase in Power as you acquire larger sets. Players must balance optimal placement, set values, and disrupt their opponents' sets. You'll also need to manage monsters, which award points when grouped together or placed on matching terrain.

The game includes everything needed for up to 5 players: over 120 terrain tiles, over 100 monster tokens, 5 double-sided player boards, a scorepad, and more.

—description from the publisher (updated for added content)

Black-Pot is played on a board of 109 squares (11x11 with the corners removed) on which players take turns to add tokens of their color, with the object of forming five tokens in a row.

Each square has a number on it and on a player's turn they roll three dice then use the numbers on the dice singly or in combination to determine which squares they may occupy. For example if a player rolls 3–4–6, they may occupy a 13 (3+4+6), or an 18 (3x4+6), or a 12 (3x4) and a 6, or a 7 (3+4) and a 6, or a 3 and a 4 and a 6, or various other combinations.

When a five-in-a-row has been made, the five tokens are removed from the board and the player scores a varying number of points depending on the numbers used in the row — numbers that are more difficult to make score more points and a large bonus is awarded for a row which uses multiple "Black Pot" numbers, which can be made only using all three dice (such as 13, 17, 21).

This game is similar to the publishers' earlier game X-O, but the board is smaller and the scoring is different.

Bad Guy Nonsense is a unique strategic family card game where you compete to capture fantastical BAD GUYS. It features wild pop culture-rich artwork on large OVERSIZED glossy linen cards making it unlike anything else that has come before.

You’ll need all your wits and gaming skills to employ BOUNTY HUNTERS, BANDITS, BURGLARS, HEROES, MONSTERS, and a WITCH to capture high-value BAD GUY targets. Battle your opponent to steal their captures while defending your own.

The goal of the game is to score points by capturing the most Bad Guy Cards before the deck runs out. You'll need to get the right card combos to make a capture and score points. The higher the value target, the harder the combo is to acquire. You make captures and score points while the SPECIAL CARDS (HEROES, BURGLAR, BANDIT, WITCH, MONSTER) all cause massive havoc between you and your opponent(s). The game gets intense as each turn passes because once the deck runs out, the game is over. When this happens, uncaptured BAD GUYS count as negative points. So you'll want to start discarding them when the deck runs low! However, your opponent(s) may be able to pick them up and use it against you... It's impossible to tell how many turns are left as you don't know how many cards the next player will play!

—description from the designer

A chess-style abstract strategy game played on a pyramid of four boards: 12x12, 8x8, 5x5 and 1x1. Each player has a pyramid (king), a cube (rook), a cylinder (bishop), a double-pawn (knight) and 44 pawns, and the winner is the player whose pyramid ascends to the fourth (1x1) board.

The game starts with each player's pyramid, cube, cylinder and 12 pawns arranged on the first (12x12) board; the remaining 32 pawns and the double-pawn start off the board and can be introduced on the owning player's back rank in lieu of a move. A player's piece can ascend to a higher board only when two pawns or one major piece belonging to that player have been captured. Otherwise pieces move approximately as their chess equivalents, although pawns gain the ability to move in more directions when they ascend to smaller boards.

An abstract strategy game somewhat resembling checkers: each player has 20 pieces and the winner is the player who gets more of their pieces to the far side of the board. On their turn each player moves one of their pieces to an adjacent space, or captures an opposing piece on an adjacent space.

The board is a tessellation of 188 triangles, and the unique factor of the game is that each space of the board is coloured one of five colors (red, orange, yellow, green, purple) and each piece can only enter three of the five colors.

Battlespace is an Ultra Modern military tabletop solo (or cooperative) game.

The player(s) selects 4 pre-made soldiers (a battle card each, containing all the information needed) for his team.
The simple AI directs the opposition, by drawing cards and acting accordingly.

Turns are divided in 3 phases.

Winning is conditioned by succeeding the mission.

Heroes Among Us is a simplistic rule set design to give players a fast pace superhero skirmish game using any miniatures in their collection.

Played on a 2' x 2' table with players fielding 3 - 5, 28mm miniatures per side.

You will need to download the Abilities Chart to play the game.

—description from the publisher

Limited Edition promotional board game from 1982 about the city of Asheville, NC.
Each player visits the shops and businesses and collects cards as detailed on their shopping list. 
The first to return home to their residence with the travel cards for all the locations on their list, wins.

The locations and streets are real businesses in Asheville, and this game was made as a promotional item for the area.

A galaxy of adventures awaits in Expansive Universe.

This is a sandbox adventure card game that has many paths to victory: explore your planet, attempt missions on enemy planets, dominate the galactic core with your armada, or engage in ground combat.  Assemble your crew, and build your fleet.  Unlimited science fiction stories are contained in Expansive Universe.

Each player chooses a faction.  Each faction starts with a planet, a spaceship, a location, and the alpha character.  The rest of the cards for each faction that is being played get shuffled into the main deck.  Every turn, cards from the main deck are auctioned and come right into play when bought.  Players can choose whether they want to build a fleet of ships, a crew of space explorers, or maximize gold production.

The sandbox style card game features a point system, so players can get points by exploring, doing missions, winning space battles, winning ground combat, or controlling the galactic core.  Every game is different.

—description from the publisher

Adventure game, where you have to act fasts, smart and avoid beeing eaten!

DR Ramasjang is the land, where children kan meet all the famous figures like Bruno and Monster. Ramasjang is never boring nor standing still. I the Ramasjang game you'll arrive in the land of Ramasjang and help the inhabitants finding things from the well know TV shows, while you flash through secrets portals.

Each player starts by choosing a player board and three different random tokens. These are the secret things you need to find to win the game.

The youngest player starts the game, and each player takes turn rolling the dice moving around the Ramasjang Island. Each stop, has a secret token that can be turned. If the tokens mach one of the three tokens on the player board, the player may keep it, if not - it is placed on the board again. When all three tokens are collected, you must travel to the center of the Island to win.

Flash spots on the board provide secret passages to other flash spots, and if you roll a 6 - you may move the monster and catch and eat another player or block the way! Any player who's taken by the monster, must return to his starting area of the board and wait one turn before entering the island again.

Flank the Tiger a World War II game with Tanks, lots of TANKS.

There are a lot of rule sets which more accurately capture the combined arms nature of World War II combat, but these rules do not pretend to be one of them.

This game attempts to be realistic-ish in what it represents, swirling tank battles. 
 But the lack of infantry, artillery, engineering, and air power gives it more of an arcade feel than that of an actual battlefield.

The only intent with this rule set is to give players a chance to use their tank models in a fast and fun game where you get to blow stuff up and maybe even enjoy getting your own stuff blown up.

Flank the Tiger includes vehicle data for 142 vehicles (Germany, USSR, USA and UK) and has pre-filled vehicle sheets for 61 select vehicles (18 Germans, 17 Russians, 12 American, and 14 British).

A simple card game where you play as a JRPG medical herb merchant, selling herbs to adventurers and making exact change.  Coins weigh down adventurers, so try to use as few possible when making change to increase your reputation.  Special cards provide useful one-use advantages.  The player with the most gold at the end of the game wins!

Matchi is beautifully adorned, simple, 2 player game that is easy to learn, yet flexible in it's strategic options. It's engaging enough for serious players, or casual enough to enjoy while having a conversation with a friend. Not to mention, it's a superb way to pass the time during the current lock-down.

The game is presented in a classic Moroccan style lending an air of timelessness to it. It's perfect for seasoned board game players and for new-comers alike. We especially like that it does not take up a lot of room on the table, so it makes a perfect coffee date companion.

The game comes with 8 full colour hexagon tiles, 6 dice, 4 blue player markers, 4 gold player markers, an instruction booklet (with a thank you page for backers!) and a beautifully presented box that it sure to catch the eye.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get all four of their player markers into the center tile.

Players roll dice, and use the dice to perform 1 of 3 actions.

The actions include placing a player marker on the board, moving a player marker, and attacking an opponents player marker.

While the mechanics are fairly simple, it still allows for several strategic choices throughout the game, but not so many that you end up with decision paralysis.

The game runs between 15-20 minutes each and is suitable for ages 8 and older.

—description from the designer

In this frenetic word game, 2 to 6 players race to pair hexagonal tiles bearing two-letter combinations and claim four-letter words as quickly as possible. The domino style of play means every new tile changes the available letters, so players must think FA-ST. Packaged in a distinctive hexagonal box, this fast-paced game takes seconds to learn, minutes to play, and provides endless hours of fun for word-game enthusiasts of all ages.

—description from the publisher

Take the role of a Dungeon Hunter with unique stats and abilities. Battle Towers of increasingly difficult monsters. Work your way up to the Tower Boss and claim the Legendary Items to help you defeat all 7 Towers to gain ultimate victory.

Use your selected Dungeon Hunter and Battle the Tower of your choosing with the Battle Deck. The battle deck consists of Attack Cards and Defense cards. These cards are added to your Dungeon Hunters Corresponding Base Stats. After drawing 5 battle cards the battle begins. Select one of the 7 Towers to Battle.

Play the battle card of your choice down within the energy requirements. A card can only be played if you have the energy equal to the card value. Energy is spent when you play an Attack card. Energy can be gained by playing defense card. If you receive damage when playing a defense card that damage is also dealt to your energy.

Your overall attack towards the monster is your base attack stat plus the attack card you have played. Same for your defense, it is the defense card and your Base Defense stat added together. If your overall attack is higher than the monsters overall attack damage is dealt to the monster. But if the monster has a higher attacking card the damage is dealt to your Dungeon Hunters Health Points. Once the monster's health is brought down to 0 the tower shifts down and you battle the next monster.

Every two monsters beaten the Tower rewards you with a random item that can help you defeat the Tower easier. But while the Tower can help you every 5 turns the Tower throws an Event at you. Events can be good helping you gain health, items or even boost your stats. But just as good as they can be they can also be bad. Removing items, losing health, or even doubling the Monsters stats.

Only after defeating all the monsters and the Tower Boss can you gain a Legendary item to help you Battle other towers. Defeating all 7 Tower will grant you victory!

—description from the publisher

Two rulers advance on the battlefield with their retinue of greatest warriors. Each of them prepared for a duel the likes of which none have ever seen. From Chessand the great White Queen marches forth, ready to decimate his brutish opponent with her superior cunning and strategy, while the all-powerful warrior-king The Red King of Hearts advances from Carda with his superior defenses and firepower. Only one shall leave this battlefield alive, but who will it be?

Royalty is a two-player strategy dice game. Use your four dice and the varied abilities of your Heroes to outwit and strongarm you opponent and claim victory! Use these dice to move and activate the abilities of your three wildly different Heroes or go for broke and use them to activate the difficult but powerful abilities of your Royal leader! Defeat your opponent with strategic movements or burst through their forces with cunning force!

Okko – Oni Hunters is a two player cooperative game.
During a 45 minutes game, you will be a hero striding through the lands of the Pajan Empire, looking for clues in order to discover the Oni hidden within the court of the Shogun.

Prepare for investigations, fights and epic journeys in your quest to restore order in the lands of Pajan with our heroes!

But beware, make sure to fulfill your mission quick before the forces of darkness corrupt all human hearts forever...

At the beginning of the game, each player chooses a Hero who seems fit to complete the mission and beat the game board.

A Hero possesses fighting and investigating skills allowing him / her to face enemies as well as solving the challenges on the way.

Moreover, each Hero has a special ability providing an edge in some situations.

Each board represents a specific cycle as they appear in the comic-book. They have their own progression and come with specific enemies and rules.

Heroes must progress in a precise order if they want to gather enough evidence to reveal corrupt courtiers at the court of Pajan.

The game breaks down in several turns during which Heroes must achieve, one after another, the following sequence:

Draw an Enemy card.
Draw an Adventure card and keep it in hand.
Trade an Adventure card with the second player.
Spend 1 day in order to: Draw 2 Adventure cards or Play a Special card or Resolving an Encounter or Move to a new Area.
Potentially remove a Damage token from the Hero’s card.
On the board, face-down tokens represents the various courtiers at the Court of the Shogun.

Each time Heroes complete a challenge, or after they defeated the board’s “boss”, a player can flip a token or more, memorize and place it or them back face down.

At the end of the game, Heroes will have to discover 3 Oni hiding among the Shogun’s courtiers by remembering what they have learned about tokens throughout the game!

—description from the publisher

Ghost Hunters! is a classical 'roll/spin and move' game, but built in a 3D pop-up book:

You are Ghost Hunters visiting a mysterious castle to hunt and collect ghosts. Ghosts are collected by visiting the squares they live on. Traps can set you back on your task to collect the most ghosts.

There are ghosts of value 1 and 2 plus the super ghost with value 10. Catching the super ghost ends the game. The hunter with the most ghosts (i.e. sum of the collected ghosts values) wins.

At some places, you have multiple options where to go.

Four spin/roll and move games in one book:

Gladiators, Chariot Race, Escape From Pompeii, and Race for the Throne

Armor Heavy Team is an official updating and expansion of the TacForce rules published by GDW/GHQ and done with the permission of GHQ.

They cover tactical combat from 1950 to 2015. 
It is the most detailed set of rules ever written for the open market while still remaining playable.

They are broken down into three levels depending on the amount of detail the GM and players wish.

The rules include sections for

     Urban Combat,
     Combat Engineering,
     Command Control and Communication,
     Maintenance,
     Night Operations,
     Nuclear,
     Biological and Chemical
     and about every other kind of warfare that we have seen or will see.


While the base game only comes with the classic cold war era vehicles, additional vehicle sets are available.

—description from the publisher

Kapadokya is a region of Turkey where dozens of balloons take flight every morning to contemplate the first rays of the sun. A beautiful scene that we will be part of with this competitive game for 2 players. Move to the Kapadokya region and help the balloons to land, the more balloons you land, the more points you will have!

Each player on his turn must place a card in the play area that represents a balloon at an indicated altitude and if he gets an indicated number of balloons he will land and with these points that will give him victory at the end of the game

				
				
					=====================================================Kapadokya es una región de Turquía en la que todas las mañanas decenas de globos levantan el vuelo para contemplar los primeros rayos del sol. Una escena preciosa de la que formaremos parte con este juego competitivo para 2 jugadores. Trasládate a la región de Kapadokya y ayuda a los globos a aterrizar, cuantos más globos
aterrices, ¡más puntos tendrás!

Cada jugador en su turno deberá colocar una carta en la zona de juego que representara un globo en un altitud indicad y si consigue un numero indicado de globos conseguirá aterrizarlos y con esto puntos que le dará la victoria al finalizar la partida

Oymyakon, winter of 1926.

Oyamyakon is a semi-cooperative game where we will assume the role of a family from Oymyakon, the coldest inhabited city in the world. The purpose of the game is to survive the low temperatures and to be the family that has lived a winter in the best possible conditions, accumulating more and better resources, for this they must manage to put groups of 3 cards of the same type inside their house and get thus the highest number of victory points.

—description from the publisher

Wars of Yor: Basics is a simplified wargame for two or more players with a Rock – Paper – Scissors style format.

Maneuver your armies' units and plan your attacks where you have the advantage.  
Calvary beats Infantry, Infantry beats Pikemen, and Pikemen beat Calvary.  
Archers plink at range, and die in close combat.

This title includes PDF rules, and STL files for 3D printing the units.

This set includes both full units, or, for those who want to save PLA, minimal unit bases.  
Both are the same size bases so you can play with either style, or mixed, with no rule changes.

This set has some custom dice STLs, but they are not needed for play.  
You can use regular D6s and consult the Advantage chart for results.  
The dice are designed in a way to allow for as much randomness as possible, but nothing beats a casino D6 for impartial rolling.

—description from the publisher

All known dimensions of the multi-realm branch out from one place. The Bloodfields. Their endless plateaus contain blueprints of all the things that can be. But they come at a cost. The grounds require a never-ending offering of blood spilled in battle.

The first beings born off the Bloodfields had to keep them satiated through gory festivals of violence. Many have died and many have become powerful beyond comprehension, thus becoming Gods.

The Gods have then created other realms. Filled them with magic and creatures of all kinds. But with one selfish purpose in mind. To ensure a never-ending stream of the most valuable resource - blood.

Every war, every disagreement, and even the smallest quarrel between Gods is therefore settled on the Bloodfields. And Gods always bring the greatest warriors from their realms to remain invincible!

This world is driven by conflict.

Bloodfields feature dynamic and simple yet engaging gameplay. To keep things action-packed each skirmish takes up to 60 minutes and features a team of chosen ones on each side.

To make every Bloodfields experience truly unique, there is a wide range of scenarios that enhance the gameplay. Each scenario has its individual rules, dedicated terrain, and surprising events. It’s up to you to prepare the winning strategy for each occasion, whether it is an endless siege or escorting a deranged mage.

The world's first realistic surfing board game. Featuring the surf photography of Brian Bielmann, the game board and box are covered with magazine quality surf photos, making looking at the game almost as enjoyable as playing it. Roll a 10-sided die and execute the take off, drop and tube of waves on the north shore of Hawaii. If you make it past the barreling tube, you can execute a variety of maneuvers to accumulate points in search of the perfect 10. Additional surf break charts are also available to localize your Waimea Wipeout experience (not included). This is the game for surfers...but not only for surfers. Waimea Wipeout educates even the most novice of fans about the essential elements of competitive surfing, while also giving the chance of victory to all players. Unique would be an understatement for this game !

JAMIT  is a new game with FILLIT components.
If you have one FILLIT set, you can play two different games!
Enjoy FILLIT & JAMIT!!

FILLIT : https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/262806/fillit

Push coins into game board from around like as pusher game.
You win when you get a certain number points as push coins out.
You should arrange your point coins to be advantageous.
This is very tactical and abstractry game.
You can enjoy this game with only FILLIT components.

—description from the designer

Bomber Boys is a dice rolling and dice allocation game with a WWII theme. You are managing the crew of an Allied aircraft during a series of air operations. To win, you have to complete each of the given missions, and each mission ends with a target that you have to bomb for a major victory. The game comes with five missions of progressive difficulty, and gameplay is based on a combination of decision making and luck.

Description from Solitaire Times website

High in the mountains, the realm of Inkalam is known for its fertile cornfields, herds of vigorous llamas, and the beauty of the lacustrine cities. But it’s especially his messengers’ guild, the Chascis, which makes it so famous.
Inkalam's prosperity depends on the quality of the messages transmitted by the Chascis. You will have to ensure the messages get delivered during a long day, from dawn to sunset.

The first player rolls the 3 dice, chooses one and puts it aside. Then all other players can choose one of the values presented by the 2-remaining dice.

Each player writes the chosen value on one of the Messages located on a Road starting from an already circled Messenger. Then they have to circle the Messenger at the other end of the Road.

If all the Messages located on the Roads surrounding a Region contain consecutive numbers (not necessarily in order), the player cross off a box of the Resource of this Region on their Scoreboard, starting with the lowest value. The next time for this Resource, the player will cross off the next higher value. At the end of the game, for each Resources (Lacustrine City, Corn Fields, and Lamas Herd), each player adds the value of the last box crossed off and the Speed Bonus if checked. Then player add the other bonus/malus of the game.

When you write on a Solar Message, check the Clock which tracks the game length. Once a player has checked the 8th sun on their clock, the game ends !

Add values for surrounded regions and any applicable speed bonuses and compare your scores.

Inkalam comes with two solo variants.

—description from the publisher

In MadCash, players start with nothing but the shirts on their backs and race to accumulate wealth any way they can. There are several ways players can accumulate cash, including getting jobs and gambling, but the trick is getting it into their bank account before they lose it.

The game board is a racetrack complete with a shortcut and spaces designed to create action or force decisions on every turn. Players use dice to move around the board and acquire Jobs (and a subsequent salary), receive Emails, collect cash payouts, and perform variety of other actions. Everyone starts by using dice and can use cash they collect to invest in other forms of transportation which allow them to strategically use up to 3 dice each roll, this also increases their job salary and the frequency at which they get paid.

There is a deck of Email cards with corresponding email spaces on the board that subject the players to a variety of events good and bad including salary increases, bills, and cards with the power to hinder other players' progress. Once players collect cash, they try to land on an ATM space in order to deposit into their bank account. Until a player's cash is safely deposited into the bank, it is fair game and can be stolen by other players, or lost in several other ways.

MadCash can be played individually or as teams with goal of accumulating a bank balance of $50,000. Game duration can vary greatly because of the volatility and unpredictability of the game play.

The game is designed in the tradition of other financial race games like Monopoly and Parker Brothers Full House, but with more of a ruthless, backstabbing element with no player ever truly being out of the race until the game is over.

—description from the designer

Join the Super Squad to Resolve Social Dilemmas by Defending the City of Empathropolis against the Evil Villain Goobi!

Received 7 major awards in the toy & game industry:
1. 2021 Board Game of the Year Award of Creative Child Magazine
2. Staff Fave Hot Diggity Award Winner 2021
3. Tillywig Brain Child Award
4. Family Choice Award 2021
5. 2022 Board Game of the Year Award of Creative Child Magazine
6. 2022 Mom’s Choice Silver Award
7. 2022 Taiwan Prime Silver Award

Endorsed by:

     California Association of Marriage Family Therapy
     U.S. Association for Play Therapy
     California Teachers Association
     Community College Association
     National Association for Bilingual Education
     California Association of Resource & Special Educators Plus
     Tri-Valley SELPA (Special Education Local Plan Area) 
     The Future of Mental Healthcare West


WHAT THIS GAME IS ABOUT:
The citizens of the city Empathropolis have been under heavy emotional duress ever since the villain Goobi has made the city sewers his new home, Apathalypse. 
 He goes about town casting spells of emotional confusion on otherwise everyday, normal situations.

Fortunately, Empathropolis has its very own team of superheroes to the rescue!

As members of the Super Squad, you are thereby summoned to patrol and restore the City back to peace.

As you chase Goobi around the city, various City Watch scenarios are unveiled as you identify as many emotions and appropriate responses are at play. You will gain powers to strengthen your emotional powers and use them to banish Goobi back to his sewers.

This cooperative game and Exploration Guidebook help children develop emotional awareness and empathy with a positive growth mindset by transforming them into superheroes with superpowers that can resolve any social dilemma.

Our Teaching Approaches:

     Step into 160+ unique City Watch Scenarios to be mindful with thoughts, feelings and actions 
     Master emotional awareness with 28 different feelings
     Sharpen communication skills through self-reflection with 80+ Power Up cards
     Exercise empathy every day with our easy-to-use evidence-based exploration guidebook
     Learn and practice important emotional and communication skills while having silly fun!


Our Board Game Design:

     Quick to set up
     Easy to learn
     Professional graphic designs
     Self-contained inbox storage for easy cleanup
     Extra Dense high-quality handmade game box for durability and keepsake
     Custom made Double-A Extra High-Density Premium 5-ply 2.5mm white cardboard for all game components 
     Printed with Soy Ink®
     100% environmentally friendly and recyclable


Playing the Game:

     Place all configurable City Blocks, Power Blocks, and Sewer Holes GRAY side up, RED side down in any slots on the board slots. Every single play will be different.
     All Superheroes start at the Start Block; Goobi, the villain is placed at the center circle of the board, his Sewer.
     Players spin to determine whether to move a Superhero or Goobi. Dice roll determines the number of steps to advance forward or the sewer number to emerge from. 
     If the spinner stops at either of the Superhero quadrants, the player may choose ANY Superhero game piece to move.
     Whichever city block the Villain lands on, flip over the City Block to RED. 
     When Superhero lands on a RED City Block, player must draw a City Watch™ Scenario Card to assess the situation by using the Feeling Cards and the Thoughts-Feelings-Actions prompt.
     After solving the scenario, the RED City Block can be turned back to normal - GRAY.
     If a Superhero lands on a Power Block, the player must draw a Power-Up™ Card and discuss the question on the card. After discussion, player keeps the Power-Up™ Card to: 


        1) Send Goobi back to Sewer, 
        2) Select to turn over any RED City Block back to Gray, or 
        3) Make Goobi stay in the sewer at its turn.

     If Goobi lands on a power block, it immediately goes back to its sewer.
     If BOTH superhero and Goobi lands on the same block: 


1) Superhero is thrown into the sewer, 
        2) The block turns RED, and 
        3) The rest of the super squad must use the Feelings Card deck (roll dice to determine how many feelings to select randomly) to act out. After the rescue, player rolls dice to determine which sewer hole the Superhero may emerge from.

To Win The Game:

     Strategize with the entire team of Super Squad to turn most, if not all, RED City Blocks back to Gray.
     All members of the Super Squad must pass the predetermined round (Start Block) to complete the mission.
     Keep the Villain in his sewer to cause the least damage to the City Blocks.
     Collect as many Power-Up Cards as you can to keep the Villain in his sewer and/or turn the Red city block back to gray.
     Identify as many Emotions as you can with each City Watch™ patrol.  


—description from the publisher

Child game based on the movie swedish movie "Bamse och häxans dotter". Roll a die and collect gold from the lake. But watch out, Krösus Sork (the thief) wants to steal your gold.

On your turn you roll a dice and get either gold from the pond or diving equipment. If you are unlucky and hit the thief's symbol, you will lose gold. If you hit the "Bamses" symbol, he retrieves all the gold from the thief and gives it back to you. The first person to collect six gold dumplings wins the game.

—user summary

"Banditen!" it is a tactical wargame covering two battles between Italian Partisans and forces of the R.S.I (Repubblica Sociale Italiana).

Tarnova is a simulation of the battle fought on 19-21 January 1945 at Tarnova della Selva, near Gorizia.

Gravellona Toce is a simulation of the battle fought on 12-14 December 1944 at Gravellona Toce, 110 km NE of Torino.

Japan-China-Korea; Three Kingdoms Modern Naval Battles is a board simulation game that depicts the possible conflict between the Japanese Maritime Self-Defense Force, the Chinese Navy and the Korean Navy that could be fought in 202x.

In this simulation, each surface ship/submarine is one unit, and each unit has anti-ship, anti-air, anti-submarine power, and technical level. In addition, wide area anti-air power must be set for Aegis warship. The character of each individual ship and each weapon is reproduced.

As a result, various modern naval battles including ship-to-ship, ship-to-air, ship-to-submarine, air-to-submarine, and air-to-air combat are reproduced with a simple game system, enabling you to play a three-dimensional modern naval-air battle.

In addition to four introductory scenarios that can be played in a short period of time, a campaign scenario that requires a plan of operations combining surface, submarine, and aircraft units on a wide scale is also included.

198 counters
1 full map
Time scale: 16 hours to 3 days (depending on scenario)
Unit scale: 1 ship /Several aircrafts
Game area: West Japan Sea and East China Sea

Scenarios:
     ãƒ»Dokdo ship, sortie! (Introduction scenario: Japan vs Korea)
     ãƒ»Senkaku offshore carrier battle (Introduction scenario: Japan vs China)
     ãƒ»Jeju Island Defense War (Introduction scenario: China vs South Korea)
     ãƒ»Aircraft carrier Izumo (Introduction scenario: Japan vs ?)
     ãƒ»Sakishima Islands Campaign (Main scenario: Japan vs China)

(translated and adapted from publisher's Japanese description)


Issue game of Game Journal #74.

This game was attached to the ioGioco 16 magazine

Peloponnesian War: Sparta and Athens face off in a clash.
Ares and Athena, patron deities of the two city-states, direct the strategies of their respective sides by communicating with the forces on the battlefield through the souls of the deceased warriors.
But this time, even the gods took the field ... and the clash will be more epic than ever!

In this game the armies of Athens and Sparta face each other. The pawns move on a squared battlefield.
But there is also another squared board, the realm of the dead, where the souls of warriors end up when they die on the battlefield.
Each turn a player moves one token into the realm of the living and one into the realm of the dead.
The position of the souls of the deceased warriors will determine the possible movements of the living warriors who fight together with the deities.
